conclusion: Objects A and B are at rest with masses 5 kg and 10 kg, respectively; gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
Setup involves three ropes: OP, OA, and OB; OB is horizontal, OP is at 45° with vertical.
Need to find tension magnitudes in ropes OP, OA, and OB.
Object A hangs from point O via rope OA; object B is on a horizontal surface connected to O via rope OB.
Forces on objects must be in equilibrium since both are at rest.
Object A is subject to its weight downward and tension in rope OA upward.
Weight of A is 50 N downward; tension in rope OA is 50 N upward.
Object B is subject to its weight downward, tension in rope OB horizontal, and normal force upward.
Weight of B is 100 N downward.
Assuming no friction, tension in OB must be equal to horizontal component of other forces.
Reconsider forces: OB is horizontal, weight and normal force are vertical, so tension OB must be zero.
Consider forces at point O where ropes OP, OA, and OB meet; tensions must balance for equilibrium.
Vector sum of tensions in OP, OA, and OB must be zero.
Establish coordinate system: vertical as y, horizontal as x.
Determine directions of tensions: OA is vertical, OB is horizontal, OP is at 45° from vertical.
Tension OP has both vertical and horizontal components.
Sum of forces in x-direction: T_OP,x + T_OB = 0.
Sum of forces in y-direction: T_OP,y + T_OA = 0.
Components of T_OP: T_OP,x = T_OP sin(45°), T_OP,y = T_OP cos(45°).
T_OA is known to be 50 N.
